[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #63](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/63/) ABORTED

The current guarantee is this:
Old driver config files will still work under the old launcher.
New driver config files will incorporate ErrorHandlerRID and LaunchID into them. If new driver config files are read by the old launcher, a configuration merge conflict will occur.

Thus, new driver config generated by the new code will need to be read by the new launcher. The old driver config generated by the old code will need to be read by the old launcher.

Is this guarantee enough for backward compatibility?

I'm kind of done with my pass. One thing I can't wrap my head around is the dualism between `InputSplit` and `DataPartition`. I believe `DataPartition` is the more general concept, right? As in: a `DataPartition` is a set of `InputSplit`s with a `location`, referencing the physical location of the data.

However, `InputSplit` does provide its locations already. And not all of the `InputSplit`s in a `DataPartition` need to reference the same locations.

[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #76](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/76/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request

@markusweimer 
I made the changes we talked about. Renamed bunch of things and clean up some stuff, like the init method in the strategy interface.
Tested DataLoadingREEF, BGD and my app and everything seems to be working.
I also decided not to create a different DataLoader, it would have been much the same code. I tried to reuse as much code as possible (that is why I included that Abstract strategy). I know we should favor composition over inheritance, but I think in this case it is OK to have a base "template" class.
Ready for review again.

[Reef-pull-request-windows2 #80](https://builds.apache.org/job/Reef-pull-request-windows2/80/) UNSTABLE
Looks like there's a problem with this pull request
I've done another pass. The tests pass, BTW.
@taegeonum This pull request does not make much sense to me. Can you explain why you are optimizing this "test"?
@bgchun `LocalNameResolverImpl` lookups `NameServer` directly. We don't need to use `NameClient` (looking up `NameServer` by using `Transport`)  if the `NameServer` is in the same node.

I do understand that what `LocalNameResolverImpl` does. Do you have a use case for local resolution? If so, it makes sense to have `LocalNameResolverImpl` and have two tests --- prior one and new one.

You're making a test that does not exercise the path that involves `Transport`, which is not good.

The JIRA description is confusing to me. I'm confused.
Please update the description if it does not reflect what you do.

On Tue, Jul 14, 2015 at 1:57 PM, Tae-Geon Um notifications@github.com
wrote:

> @bgchun https://github.com/bgchun Yes. In Driver, user can use both
> NameServer and NameClient. In this case, LocalNameResolverImpl can be
> used.
> 
> Sorry, I didn't quite understand your question. I just refactored previous
> test code, in order to remove repetitive code. I didn't optimise the test.
> NameClient uses Transport when looking up NameServer, but
> LocalNameResolver does not use Transport. Do I understand correctly?
> 
> 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/apache/incubator-reef/pull/294#issuecomment-121133163
> .

## 

Byung-Gon Chun
@bgchun Oh, I see. I think it is confusing.  I will update the description. Thanks :)

@shravanmn and @bgchun, I've addressed your comments in the push I just made. Could you take another look?
- Our discussion on the Scatter API on [REEF-126](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-126) ended without a conclusion, so I left all methods in (all implemented) for now.
- Lexicographical order on task ids is taken when no other order is specified, both for Scatter and Gather. 
- I also included a couple of tests for the helper classes, but didn't write any other tests since we have [REEF-187](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/REEF-187). Nonetheless, I have confirmed that all Gather APIs and Scatter APIs function correctly by slightly modifying the BroadcastREEF example, not included here.
